_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

Trivial, insignificant details of mere e: The ascetic Gotama has given up killing living creatures.
The ascetic Gotama has given up stealing.
The ascetic Gotama has given up unchastity.
The ascetic Gotama has given up lying.
The ascetic Gotama has given up divisive speech.
The ascetic Gotama has given up harsh speech.
The ascetic Gotama has given up talking nonsense.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from injuring plants and seeds.
He eats in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
He refrains from dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.
He refrains from beautifying and adorning himself with garlands, perfumes, and makeup.
He refrains from high and luxurious beds.

He refrains from receiving gold and money, raw grains, raw meat, women and girls, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants, cows, horses, and mares, and fields and land.

He refrains from running errands and messages; buying and selling; falsifying weights, metals, or measures; bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
Ascetics and brahmins who engage in cert: Engage in injuring plants and seeds
Engage in storing up goods for their own use
Engage in seeing shows
Engage in gambling that causes negligence
Make use of high and luxurious bedding
Engage in beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup
Engage in unworthy talk
Engage in arguments
Engage in running errands and messages
Engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material possessions to chase after other material possessions
Injuring plants and seeds

The ordinary person's praise of the Real: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such injury to plants and seeds.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from storing up such goods.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such shows.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such gambling.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such bedding.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such beautification and adornment.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy talk.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such argumentative talk.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such errands.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such deceit and flattery.
Unworthy branches of knowledge, wrong li: Limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the crafts of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying life span, chanting for protection, and deciphering animal cries.

Reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.

Making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.

Making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery sky, an earthquake, thunder; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.

Predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as computing, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.

Making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, causing abortions, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.

Rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs.

Limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the crafts of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying life span, chanting for protection, and deciphering animal cries.

Reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.

Making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.

Making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery sky, an earthquake, thunder; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.

Predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as computing, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.

Making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, causing abortions, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.

Rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs.
Theories about the past [dn1:1.21.0]: Theorizing about the past and asserting various hypotheses concerning the past on eighteen grounds.
The eighteen grounds on which they rely.
The four grounds on which some ascetics: When some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.

When some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives, that is, one eon of the cosmos contracting and expanding; two, three, four, five, or ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding.

When some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right focus—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives, that is, ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding; twenty, thirty, or forty eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding.
When some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry.
The four grounds on which partial eterna: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.
There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.
There are gods named ‘depraved by play.’
When some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry.
There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.
There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.
There are gods named ‘depraved by play.’
Some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry.
The characteristics of the gods who are: They don’t spend too much time gazing at each other.
They don’t grow angry with each other.
Their bodies and minds don’t get tired.
They don’t pass away from that host of gods.
They don’t spend too much time laughing, playing, and making merry.
They don’t pass away from that host of gods.
The characteristics of the being who was: They are Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
They are more long-lived, beautiful, and illustrious than those who arrived later.
The characteristics of the beings who we: They think that the being who was reborn there first is Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
They were created by that Brahmā.
They are impermanent, not lasting, short-lived, perishable, and have come to this state of existence.
Ordinary person's praise of the Realized: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such injury to plants and seeds.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from storing up such goods.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such shows.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such gambling.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such bedding.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such beautification and adornment.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such unworthy talk.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such argumentative talk.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such errands.
The ascetic Gotama refrains from such deceit and flattery.
The eighteen grounds on which ascetics a: That the world is not eternal
That the soul and the body are the same
That the soul is one thing and the body another
That the Realized One exists after death
That the Realized One does not exist after death
That the Realized One both exists and does not exist after death
That the Realized One neither exists nor does not exist after death
That the world is the same everywhere
That the world is different everywhere
That the soul is the same as the body in every way
That the soul is one thing and the body another in every way
That the Realized One is a Tathāgata
That the Realized One is not a Tathāgata
That the Realized One both is and is not a Tathāgata
That the Realized One neither is nor is not a Tathāgata
The four grounds on which some ascetics: The first ground - recollection of many kinds of past lives
The second ground - recollection of one or more eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding
The third ground - recollection of ten or more eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding
The fourth ground - reliance on logic and inquiry
The destiny in the next life (a causal s: If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views
It leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.
The four grounds on which some ascetics: When some ascetic or brahmin experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite
When some ascetic or brahmin experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as infinite
When some ascetic or brahmin experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they meditate perceiving the cosmos as finite vertically but infinite horizontally
When some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry
The four grounds on which equivocators r: The first ground - fear and disgust with false speech
The second ground - fear and disgust with grasping
The third ground - fear and disgust with examination
The fourth ground - dullness and stupidity
The questions asked by the dull and stup: Whether there are beings who are reborn spontaneously
Whether there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds
Whether a Realized One exists after death
Whether a Realized One doesn’t exist after death
Whether a Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death
Whether a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.
The two grounds on which some ascetics a: Non-percipient beings passing away from that host and being reborn in this state of existence
Ascetics or brahmins relying on logic and inquiry

The soul is one thing and the body another

The soul is one thing and the body another
The Tathāgata is both sense-perceptible and not sense-perceptible
The Tathāgata is neither sense-perceptible nor not sense-perceptible.

The world is infinite

The Tathāgata is not and will not be after death
The Tathāgata both is and will be after death
The Tathāgata neither is nor will be after death
The Tathāgata is and will be not after death
The Tathāgata is not and will be after death
The Tathāgata both is not and will be after death
The Tathāgata neither is not nor will be after death
The world is eternal and finite
The world is eternal and infinite
The world is not eternal and finite
The world is not eternal and infinite
The world is both eternal and finite, and not eternal and finite
The world is both eternal and finite, and not eternal and infinite
The world is both eternal and infinite, and not eternal and finite

The world is both not eternal and finite, and not eternal and infinite
The world is both not eternal and finite, and not not eternal and infinite
The world is both not eternal and infinite, and not eternal and finite
The world is both not eternal and infinite, and not not eternal and finite
The world is neither eternal nor finite, nor not eternal nor finite
The world is neither eternal nor infinite, nor not eternal nor infinite
The world is neither not eternal nor finite, nor not not eternal nor finite
The world is neither not eternal nor infinite, nor not not eternal nor infinite
The world is both eternal and finite, and eternal and infinite, and not eternal and finite, and not eternal and infinite
The world is neither eternal nor finite, nor eternal nor infinite, nor not eternal nor finite, nor not eternal nor infinite.
The sixteen grounds on which some asceti: The self is well and percipient after death, and it is physical
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is non-physical
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is both physical and non-physical
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is neither physical nor non-physical
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is finite
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is infinite
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is both finite and infinite
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is neither finite nor infinite
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is of unified perception
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is of diverse perception
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is of limited perception
The self is well and percipient after death, and it is of limitless perception
The self is well and percipient after death, and it experiences nothing but happiness
The self is well and percipient after death, and it experiences nothing but suffering
The self is well and percipient after death, and it experiences both happiness and suffering
The self is well and percipient after death, and it experiences neither happiness nor suffering.
The eight grounds on which some ascetics: The self is well and non-percipient after death, and it is physical
The self is well and non-percipient after death, and it is non-physical
The self is well and non-percipient after death, and it is both physical and non-physical
The self is well and non-percipient after death, and it is neither physical nor non-physical

The self is well and non-percipient after death, and it is neither finite nor infinite.
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is physical
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is non-physical
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is both physical and non-physical
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is neither physical nor non-physical
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is finite
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is infinite
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is both finite and infinite
The self is well and neither percipient nor non-percipient after death, and it is neither finite nor infinite.
The seven grounds on which some ascetics: The self is physical, made up of the four primary elements, and produced by mother and father.
There is another self that is divine, physical, sensual, consuming solid food.
There is another self that is divine, physical, mind-made, complete in all its various parts, not deficient in any faculty.

There is another self which has gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, it’s reborn in the dimension of infinite space.
There is another self which has gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that “consciousness is infinite”, it’s reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
There is another self that has gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that “there is nothing at all”, it’s been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

There is another self that has gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. Aware that “this is peaceful, this is sublime”, it’s been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

Dependent Origination [dn1:3.71.0] (a ca: Old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
